title: 70,000 unearthed images of Idi Amin show the propaganda used to create a 'jovial' profile'
text:
Advertisement

Unearthed photographs of the late Ugandan dictator Idi Admin have revealed the 'magic energy' that was 'behind his brutality'.

A whopping 70,000 images were found in a locked cabinet at the Ugandan state broadcaster's office and show how the notorious dictator was able to easily manipulate the media.

Some of the previously unseen pictures give a closer look into Amin's cruel practises such as the arrest and humiliation of alleged petty criminals before their executions.

But others seem to show Amin, who was responsible for the deaths of 100,000 to 500,000 people, in a different light. In one image, Amin is surrounded by children at a party with a big cake.

Unearthed photographs of the late Ugandan dictator Idi Admin have revealed the 'magic energy' that was 'behind his brutality'. Pictured is Idi Amin dancing at Uganda's Refugee Day

Idi Amin, who is believed to be responsible for the death of 100,000 to 500,000 people, is pictured with Miss Tourism pageant contestants in 1978

A whopping 70,000 images were found in a locked cabinet at the Ugandan state broadcaster's office and show how the notorious dictator was able to easily manipulate the media

And others show him playing the accordion and relaxing at the beach.

Amin, who was also known as the 'Butcher of Uganda', launched a military coup in 1971 and declared himself President.

Throughout his eight-year rule he ordered the death of multiple ethnic communities in Uganda, in an attempt to leave only his people - the Kakwas.

Amin also targeted anyone who could show any potential disloyalty and ordered the killings of journalists, judges, business people, artists, officials and clerics.

They were abducted, tortured and killed before being thrown into the River Nile.

Dr Richard Vokes, an anthropologist with the University of Western Australia, told the Guardian that the photographs - which he helped to discover - show a 'kind of magic energy' that was 'behind the brutality and part of the brutality'.

He said: 'We see how Amin embraced the media and understood its power.

'He had a great sense of how media could amplify his ego and his political will.'

A selection of the pictures, which were taken by photographers from the information industry, are being put on display at Uganda's national museum and have received mixed reviews.

While Amin's relatives are thrilled with the exhibition, families of his victims are concerned that the photographs will hide the reality of his brutality.

Sarah Bananuka, 69, whose father and three brothers were murdered under Amin's rule, told the Guardian: 'In these pictures you see him enjoying life. We don't see the other side of Amin, which we felt, lived and experienced.'

Amin was born in 1925 to a Kakwa farmer father and Lugbara mother, either in Koboko or Kampala.

In 1946 he joined the King's African Rifles for the British Colonial Army, as a cook.

He quickly rose through the ranks and became lieutenant. When Uganda gained independence from the UK in 1962, Amin stayed in the army and eventually became its commander.

The 1971 military coup he launched against President Milton Obote was precipitated by Obote's plans to arrest Amin for misappropriating military funds.

Amin began his dictatorship with backing from much of the western world but by the end of his rule he was supported only by Libiya's Colonel Gadaffi, the Soviet Union and East Germany.

He quickly rose through the ranks and became lieutenant. When Uganda gained independence from the UK in 1962, Amin stayed in the army and eventually became its commander

The dictator was a polygamist and married six women, three of whom he divorced.

He is also suspecting of torturing and killing one of his wives, Kay Amin, after she was found dismembered in 1974.

He expelled all Asians from Uganda in 1972, leading to the breakdown of Uganda's economy.

After the UK broke off diplomatic relations with the regime in 1977, Amin declared that he had conquered the country and gave himself the title CBE (conqueror of the British Empire).

Amin began his dictatorship with backing from much of the western world but by the end of his rule he was supported only by Libiya's Colonel Gadaffi, the Soviet Union and East Germany

He eventually made his name His Excellency, President for Life, Field Marshal Al Hadji Doctor Idi Amin Dada, VC, DSO, MC, Lord of All the Beasts of the Earth and Fishes of the Seas and Conqueror of the British Empire in Africa in General and Uganda in Particular.

He also claimed to be the uncrowned King of Scotland which led to the 2006 drama called The Last King of Scotland about Amin's rule.

Amin was ousted by exiled Ugandans in 1979 after he invaded Tanzania, and was attacked by the Uganda National Liberation Front.

It was widely believed that Amin was a cannibal but he is reported to have said that human flesh was 'too salty' for his tastes.

He died in exile in Saudi Arabia in 2003.
description: Some 70,000 previously unseen images have been unearthed from a locked cabinet at the Ugandan state broadcaster's office. They show the late dictator cutting cake with children and smiling.
